title: pregnancy
text: easily keep vignette fairly --date, prevent recurring package build CRAN failures time goes , hard-coded dates . Instead, calculated everything date vignette built. November 18, 2025, purposes reading page, counts “today”. pregnancy package uses dates extensively. function argument requires date can either take Date object1, character string can parsed Date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". parsing performed anytime::anydate().

title: pregnancy
text: calculate_due_date() function estimates pregnancy due date. start_date interpreted differently, depending start_type. default, start_type last menstrual period, start_date date started. start_date options, like various transfer days, useful using IVF. due date know, how_far() tells far along pregnancy given date. defaults providing information current date, alternative on_date can provided. See section global options avoid needing pass due_date value every time call function. date_when() function gives date certain week pregnancy () reached, duration date today: default, output messages how_far() date_when() second person, .e. addressed “”, also option specify another person. value 1 "" means ’ll addressed first person: character string interpreted third-person name, useful, example, ’re following pregnancy progress partner: one date-related function package, useful yet pregnant think ’s chance might , e.g. undergoing fertility treatment. calculate_test_date(), calculates recommended date taking pregnancy test, based start date (e.g. start last menstural period) test type:
code: # for purpose of vignette, calculate `start_date` relative to "today" today <- Sys.Date() start_date <- today - 192  # invisibly returns a Date object with the estimated due date # by default, start date of last menstrual period, but other options available # in practice, the start_date argument will be a known date, e.g. "2025-05-29" due_date <- calculate_due_date(start_date) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Saturday, February 14, 2026 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: January 24, 2026 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: February 28, 2026 (42 weeks) how_far(due_date = due_date) #> ℹ You are 27 weeks and 3 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 12 weeks and 4 days until the due date (February 14, 2026). #> ℹ You are 69% through the pregnancy. how_far(on_date = today + 1, due_date = due_date) #> ℹ On November 19, 2025, you will be 27 weeks and 4 days #> pregnant. date_when(33, due_date = due_date) #> ℹ On December 27, 2025, you will be 33 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That's 5 weeks and 4 days away. how_far(due_date = due_date, person = 1) #> ℹ I am 27 weeks and 3 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 12 weeks and 4 days until the due date (February 14, 2026). #> ℹ I am 69% through the pregnancy. date_when(33, due_date = due_date, person = "Ruth") #> ℹ On December 27, 2025, Ruth will be 33 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That's 5 weeks and 4 days away. calculate_test_date(today - 20) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Wednesday, November 26, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Monday, November 24, 2025

title: pregnancy
text: get pregnant via fertility treatment, likely need take number different medications support pregnancy. functionality tracking useful practical emotional reasons. pregnant, personal, private pregnancy package, whenever called version how_far, print message many injections already endured, many left go, helped get . haven’t written functionality how_far() generalised version pregnancy package, provided separate medications_remaining() function keep track medications. requires data frame medications, must following columns specified data types: Note quantity given medication changes pregnancy, need separate rows start stop dates quantity. ’s example simple medications table might look like: can calculate quantity medications left take grouped either medication (default) format. default, calculation today (.e. on_date = Sys.Date()). resulting table assumes function called first thing day, .e. on_date’s medications taken. can specify value today on_date, well until_date. useful need () order couple week’s medication time, tell pharmacy exactly need:
code: # a simplified medication schedule meds <- pregnancy:::update_meds_table(pregnancy::medications_simple) meds #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   medication format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>   <chr>      <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #> 1 progynova  tablet           3 2025-11-04 2025-11-14 #> 2 progynova  tablet           6 2025-11-15 2025-11-25 #> 3 cyclogest  pessary          2 2025-11-17 2025-11-25 #> 4 clexane    injection        1 2025-11-22 2026-01-19 medications_remaining(meds) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication quantity #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 clexane          59 #> 2 cyclogest        16 #> 3 progynova        48 medications_remaining(meds, group = "format") #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   format    quantity #>   <chr>        <int> #> 1 injection       59 #> 2 pessary         16 #> 3 tablet          48 medications_remaining(   meds,   on_date = today + 3,   until_date = today + 17 ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication quantity #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 clexane          14 #> 2 cyclogest        10 #> 3 progynova        30

title: pregnancy
text: tedious enter due date every time call how_far() date_when() course pregnancy, especially since date constant throughout. goes medications table required medications_remaining(). avoid , pregnancy package makes use global options, can set set_* family functions (set_due_date(), set_person(), set_medications()). functions set options current R session. ensure options persist across R sessions, suggest setting .Rprofile, give example end vignette. Global options can retrieved get_* family functions (get_due_date(), get_person(), get_medications()). global option can unset calling set_* function argument NULL.

title: pregnancy
text: can set pregnancy.due_date option using set_due_date() function. option set, due_date argument how_far() date_when() NULL (default), option retrieved. set_due_date() sets due date current R session. make option persist (recommended), can added .Rprofile. console output set_due_date() provides guidance . how_far() can called without needing specify arguments, date_when() needs target week: check option set , use get_due_date().
code: # a different due date from the earlier example due_date <- today + 180 set_due_date(due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as May 17, 2026 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. how_far() #> ℹ You are 14 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 25 weeks and 5 days until the due date (May 17, 2026). #> ℹ You are 36% through the pregnancy. date_when(20) #> ℹ On December 28, 2025, you will be 20 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That's 5 weeks and 5 days away.

title: pregnancy
text: set_person() sets global option pregnancy.person current R session. option set retrieved specify value person how_far() date_when(), unless overriden passing another value directly person argument. option set, default second-person used.
code: set_person(1) #> ✔ person set as 'I' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. how_far() # due_date option still set from previous section #> ℹ I am 14 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 25 weeks and 5 days until the due date (May 17, 2026). #> ℹ I am 36% through the pregnancy. set_person(NULL) #> ✔ pregnancy.person option set to NULL. #> ℹ The `person` argument will now default to "You". how_far() #> ℹ You are 14 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 25 weeks and 5 days until the due date (May 17, 2026). #> ℹ You are 36% through the pregnancy.

title: pregnancy
text: set_medications() sets global option pregnancy.medications current R session. option set, meds argument medications_remaining() NULL (default), option retrieved.
code: set_medications(pregnancy:::update_meds_table(pregnancy::medications)) #> ✔ medications set. #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`. medications_remaining() #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   medication   quantity #>   <chr>           <int> #> 1 LDA                 4 #> 2 clexane           120 #> 3 cyclogest         138 #> 4 lubion             69 #> 5 prednisolone      289 #> 6 progynova         414

title: pregnancy
text: Taking advice specify options .Rprofile, ’s example might look like: Note best avoid creating R objects .Rprofile, e.g. medications data frame outside call options(), otherwise object loaded global environment start every R session.
code: options(   pregnancy.due_date = "2025-09-16",   pregnancy.person = "I", # addressed in first person   pregnancy.medications = dplyr::tribble(     ~medication, ~format, ~quantity, ~start_date, ~stop_date,     "progynova", "tablet", 3, "2025-04-21", "2025-04-30",     "progynova", "tablet", 6, "2025-05-01", "2025-07-11",     "cyclogest", "pessary", 2, "2025-05-03", "2025-07-11",     "clexane", "injection", 1, "2025-05-08", "2025-09-05"   ) )

what: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
text: R package calculating dates tracking medications pregnancy fertility treatment. extends private, personal package wrote pregnant. contains functions features found useful time, others added adapting package general use. functionality goes beyond ’s offered online pregnancy calculators apps, plus concerns (unlike sites apps) data privacy, tracking advertising.

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
text: pregnancy available CRAN: can install development version R-universe: Alternatively, install development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("pregnancy") install.packages("pregnancy", repos = "https://ellakaye.r-universe.dev") pak::pak("EllaKaye/pregnancy")

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
text: quick tour. extensive guide, see Get Started vignette.
code: library(pregnancy)

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
text: easily keep document fairly --date, prevent recurring package build CRAN failures time goes , hard-coded dates. Instead, calculated everything date README last built. November 18, 2025, purposes reading page, counts “today”.

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
code: # for purpose of README, calculate `start_date` relative to "today" today <- Sys.Date() start_date <- today - 192  # invisibly returns a Date object with the estimated due date # by default, start date of last menstrual period, but other options available # in practice, the start_date argument will be a known date, e.g. "2025-05-29" due_date <- calculate_due_date(start_date) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Saturday, February 14, 2026 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: January 24, 2026 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: February 28, 2026 (42 weeks) # set the pregnancy.due_date option # avoids having to pass the due date as argument to other functions set_due_date(due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as February 14, 2026 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. # don't need to specify `due_date` since option is set # invisibly returns number of days into the pregnancy how_far() #> ℹ You are 27 weeks and 3 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 12 weeks and 4 days until the due date (February 14, 2026). #> ℹ You are 69% through the pregnancy. # alternative `on_date`, addressed as "I" # usually `on_date` will be a fixed date, but given here relative to "today" how_far(on_date = today + 1, person = 1) #> ℹ On November 19, 2025, I will be 27 weeks and 4 days pregnant. # when a given week of the pregnancy is reached # invisibly returns the Date when that week is reached date_when(33) #> ℹ On December 27, 2025, you will be 33 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That's 5 weeks and 4 days away.

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
code: # a simplified medication schedule meds <- pregnancy:::update_meds_table(pregnancy::medications_simple) meds #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   medication format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>   <chr>      <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #> 1 progynova  tablet           3 2025-11-04 2025-11-14 #> 2 progynova  tablet           6 2025-11-15 2025-11-25 #> 3 cyclogest  pessary          2 2025-11-17 2025-11-25 #> 4 clexane    injection        1 2025-11-22 2026-01-19 # how much of each medication is left to take, as of "today" medications_remaining(meds) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication quantity #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 clexane          59 #> 2 cyclogest        16 #> 3 progynova        48 # how much medication for a given week  # (useful if you need to request a prescription to cover a certain time period) # usually, `on_date` and `until_date` would be hard-coded dates medications_remaining(meds, on_date = today + 3, until_date = today + 10) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication quantity #>   <chr>         <int> #> 1 clexane           7 #> 2 cyclogest        10 #> 3 progynova        30

title: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy
text: how_far() date_when() need know pregnancy due date, can passed directly due_date argument. tedious, however, enter due date every time call functions course pregnancy, especially since date constant throughout. holds medications table required medications_remaining(). avoid , pregnancy package makes use global options, can set set_* family functions (set_due_date(), set_person(), set_medications()), retrieved corresponding get_* family functions (get_due_date(), get_person(), get_medications()). options persist duration current R session. global option can unset calling set_* function argument NULL.
code: # a different due date from the earlier example new_due_date <- today + 180 set_due_date(new_due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as May 17, 2026 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. how_far() #> ℹ You are 14 weeks and 2 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 25 weeks and 5 days until the due date (May 17, 2026). #> ℹ You are 36% through the pregnancy. # check and then unset option get_due_date() #> ℹ Your due date is set as May 17, 2026. set_due_date(NULL) #> ✔ pregnancy.due_date option set to NULL. #> ℹ You will need to explicitly pass a value to the `due_date` argument #>   in functions that use it, or reset the option with `set_due_date()`.

what: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: Calculates estimated due date based start date type. function supports different start date types including last menstrual period (LMP), conception date, embryo transfer dates. also provides estimated birth period, spans 37 weeks (birth period start) 42 weeks (birth period end).

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
code: calculate_due_date(   start_date,   start_type = c("LMP", "conception", "transfer_day_3", "transfer_day_5",     "transfer_day_6"),   cycle = 28 )

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: start_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". starting reference date. interpretation date depends start_type parameter. start_type character. One : "LMP": Last Menstrual Period date (default) "conception": Date conception "transfer_day_3": Date day 3 embryo transfer "transfer_day_5": Date day 5 embryo transfer "transfer_day_6": Date day 6 embryo transfer cycle numeric. Length menstrual cycle days. used start_type = "LMP". Must 20 44 days. Defaults 28 days.

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: Returns Date object representing estimated due date invisibly. Also prints informative messages showing: estimated due date birth period begins (37 weeks) birth period ends (42 weeks)

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
text: due date calculated follows: LMP: Ovulation estimated start_date + cycle - 14 days, 266 days added conception: 266 days added conception date embryo transfers: appropriate number days subtracted get conception date (3, 5, 6 days), 266 days added birth period start date 21 days due date (37 weeks pregnant), birth period end date 14 days due date (42 weeks pregnant). #' start_date character string, conversion Date handled anytime::anydate().

title: Calculate estimated due date and birth period — calculate_due_date
code: # Calculate due date from last menstrual period calculate_due_date("2025-01-31") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Friday, November 07, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2025 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2025 (42 weeks)  # Calculate from conception date calculate_due_date("2025-02-14", start_type = "conception") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Friday, November 07, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2025 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2025 (42 weeks)  # Calculate from day 5 embryo transfer calculate_due_date(as.Date("2025-02-19"), start_type = "transfer_day_5") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Friday, November 07, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2025 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2025 (42 weeks)  # Calculate with non-standard cycle length calculate_due_date("2025-01-31", cycle = 35) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Friday, November 14, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 24, 2025 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 28, 2025 (42 weeks)

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: Calculates recommended date taking pregnancy test based start date type. function supports urine blood tests, blood tests typically viable 2 days earlier urine tests.

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
code: calculate_test_date(   start_date,   start_type = c("LMP", "conception", "transfer_day_3", "transfer_day_5",     "transfer_day_6"),   cycle = 28,   test_type = c("urine", "blood") )

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: start_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". starting reference date. interpretation date depends start_type parameter. start_type character. One : "LMP": Last Menstrual Period date (default) "conception": Date conception "transfer_day_3": Date day 3 embryo transfer "transfer_day_5": Date day 5 embryo transfer "transfer_day_6": Date day 6 embryo transfer cycle numeric. Length menstrual cycle days. used start_type = "LMP". Must 20 44 days. Defaults 28 days. test_type character. One : "urine": Home pregnancy test (default) "blood": Blood test clinic

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: Returns Date object invisibly representing recommended test date. Also prints informative messages showing: recommended date urine test recommended date blood test

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
text: test date calculated follows: First, ovulation date calculated (see calculate_due_date() details) urine tests: 14 days added ovulation date blood tests: 12 days added ovulation date Blood tests can typically detect pregnancy earlier urine tests due greater sensitivity detecting hCG hormone levels. start_date character string, conversion Date handled anytime::anydate().

title: Calculate pregnancy test date — calculate_test_date
code: # Calculate test date from last menstrual period calculate_test_date("2025-01-31") #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Friday, February 28, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Wednesday, February 26, 2025  # Calculate for blood test from conception date calculate_test_date(   start_date = "5023-02-14",   start_type = "conception",   test_type = "blood" ) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Friday, February 28, 5023 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Wednesday, February 26, 5023  # Calculate from day 5 embryo transfer calculate_test_date(   as.Date("2025-02-19"),   start_type = "transfer_day_5" ) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Friday, February 28, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Wednesday, February 26, 2025  # Calculate with non-standard cycle length calculate_test_date("2025-01-31", cycle = 35) #> ℹ Estimated test date (urine): Friday, March 07, 2025 #> ℹ Estimated test date (blood): Wednesday, March 05, 2025

what: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: Calculate display date specific pregnancy week

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
code: date_when(weeks, due_date = NULL, person = NULL, today = Sys.Date())

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: weeks Numeric value indicating number weeks pregnancy calculate date . due_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". expected due date. NULL, try use "pregnancy.due_date" option. Required option set. person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set. today Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". Represents reference date calculations. Default Sys.Date(). parameter exists primarily testing documentation purposes unlikely make sense user need want change default.

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: Invisibly returns Date object specified week pregnancy occurs/occurred/occur. Prints messages console showing: specified week pregnancy occurs/occurred/occur far past/future date today (unless date current date)

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
text: function calculates someone /specific number weeks pregnant based due date. handles past, present future dates appropriately messaging. due date can provided directly set globally using options("pregnancy.due_date"). Similarly, person referenced can provided directly set globally using options("pregnancy.person"). date_when today character string, conversion Date handled anytime::anydate().

title: Calculate and display date of specific pregnancy week — date_when
code: # Set a due date date_when(20, due_date = "2025-12-01") #> ℹ On July 14, 2025, you were 20 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That was 18 weeks and 1 day ago. date_when(33, due_date = as.Date("2025-12-01"), person = "Sarah") #> ℹ On October 13, 2025, Sarah was 33 weeks pregnant. #> ℹ That was 5 weeks and 1 day ago.

what: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: Functions get set default due date used throughout package. affects calculations various functions determine pregnancy progress timing. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_due_date() sets "pregnancy.due_date" option get_due_date() retrieves .

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
code: set_due_date(due_date)  get_due_date()

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: due_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD", specifying estimated due date, NULL unset option.

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: functions invisibly return current due date setting: get_due_date() returns current setting (Date object) NULL set set_due_date() returns due date value set

title: Set or get the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
code: # Store original setting (without messages) original_due_date <- getOption("pregnancy.due_date")  # Check current setting get_due_date() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.due_date` set as an option. #> ℹ You can set it with `set_due_date()`. #> ℹ You can also pass a value directly to the `due_date` argument where required.  # Set due date and check again set_due_date("2025-09-15") #> ✔ Due date set as September 15, 2025 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. get_due_date() #> ℹ Your due date is set as September 15, 2025.  # Restore original setting (without messages) options(pregnancy.due_date = original_due_date)

what: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Calculates displays far along pregnancy specific date, including weeks pregnant, days remaining due date, overall progress percentage.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: how_far(on_date = Sys.Date(), due_date = NULL, person = NULL)

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: on_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". date calculate pregnancy progress. Defaults current system date. due_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD". expected due date. NULL, try use "pregnancy.due_date" option. Required option set. person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Invisibly returns number days along pregnancy. Prints formatted message console pregnancy progress information.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: function assumes standard pregnancy length 280 days (40 weeks) calculating progress. handles past, present, future dates appropriately adjusting message grammar. calculation shows 42 weeks pregnancy, different message displayed noting unusual duration. function uses cli package formatted message output supports proper pluralization weeks/days messages. on_date due_date character strings, conversion Date handled anytime::anydate().

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: pregnancy.due_date: Date object setting default due date pregnancy.person: Character string setting default person

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: # Current progress with explicit due date # Note that output will depend on date the function is run how_far(due_date = "2025-12-01") #> ℹ You are 38 weeks and 1 day pregnant. #> ℹ That's 1 week and 6 days until the due date (December 01, 2025). #> ℹ You are 95% through the pregnancy.  # Progress on a specific date how_far(on_date = "2025-11-01", due_date = "2025-12-01") #> ℹ On November 01, 2025, you were 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant.  # With custom person how_far(on_date = "2025-11-01", due_date = "2025-12-01", person = "Sarah") #> ℹ On November 01, 2025, Sarah was 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant.  # Set global options date_opt <- getOption("pregnancy.due_date") # save current option set_due_date("2025-12-01") #> ✔ Due date set as December 01, 2025 #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `due_date` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `due_date` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.due_date = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `due_date`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. how_far() #> ℹ You are 38 weeks and 1 day pregnant. #> ℹ That's 1 week and 6 days until the due date (December 01, 2025). #> ℹ You are 95% through the pregnancy. options(pregnancy.due_date = date_opt) # return original option

what: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
title: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: Functions get set default medications data frame used medications_remaining() function. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_medications() sets "pregnancy.medications" option get_medications() retrieves .

title: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
code: set_medications(meds)  get_medications()

title: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: meds Data frame containing medication schedule. Must following columns: medication (character/factor): Name medication format (character/factor): Format medication (e.g., pill, injection) quantity (numeric): Number units take per day start_date (Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD"): Date start taking medication stop_date (Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD"): Final date medication taken NULL, try use "pregnancy.medications" option. Required option set.

title: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
text: functions invisibly return current medications setting: get_medications() returns current setting (data frame) NULL set set_medications() returns medications data frame set

title: Set or get the pregnancy.medications option — medications-option
code: # Store original setting (without messages) original_medications <- getOption("pregnancy.medications")  # Set the option set_medications(pregnancy::medications) #> ✔ medications set. #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`.  # Get the option get_medications() #> Your medications table is set as #> # A tibble: 14 × 5 #>    medication   format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>    <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #>  1 progynova    tablet           3 2025-07-21 2025-07-30 #>  2 LDA          tablet           1 2025-07-21 2025-08-07 #>  3 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-07-26 2025-08-07 #>  4 progynova    tablet           6 2025-08-01 2025-10-11 #>  5 cyclogest    pessary          2 2025-08-03 2025-10-11 #>  6 lubion       injection        1 2025-08-03 2025-10-11 #>  7 clexane      injection        1 2025-08-08 2025-12-05 #>  8 prednisolone tablet           4 2025-08-08 2025-10-11 #>  9 prednisolone tablet           3 2025-10-12 2025-10-14 #> 10 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-10-15 2025-10-17 #> 11 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-18 2025-10-20 #> 12 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-22 2025-10-22 #> 13 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-24 2025-10-24 #> 14 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-26 2025-10-26  # Restore original setting (without messages) options(pregnancy.medications = original_medications)

title: An example medications table — medications
text: data frame example medications might used fertility treatment/first trimester. example data frame might used meds argument medications_remaining().

code: medications  medications_simple

title: An example medications table — medications
text: medications data frame 14 rows 5 columns. medications_simple data frame 4 rows 5 columns. medication Name medication format Format medication quantity Number taken per day start_date Date start taking medication stop_date Final date medication taken. See details. object class tbl_df (inherits tbl, data.frame) 4 rows 5 columns.

title: An example medications table — medications
text: Note medication (prednisolone example) several rows, first quantity taken per day changes, needs taken non-consecutive days.

title: An example medications table — medications
code: medications #> # A tibble: 14 × 5 #>    medication   format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>    <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #>  1 progynova    tablet           3 2025-07-21 2025-07-30 #>  2 LDA          tablet           1 2025-07-21 2025-08-07 #>  3 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-07-26 2025-08-07 #>  4 progynova    tablet           6 2025-08-01 2025-10-11 #>  5 cyclogest    pessary          2 2025-08-03 2025-10-11 #>  6 lubion       injection        1 2025-08-03 2025-10-11 #>  7 clexane      injection        1 2025-08-08 2025-12-05 #>  8 prednisolone tablet           4 2025-08-08 2025-10-11 #>  9 prednisolone tablet           3 2025-10-12 2025-10-14 #> 10 prednisolone tablet           2 2025-10-15 2025-10-17 #> 11 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-18 2025-10-20 #> 12 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-22 2025-10-22 #> 13 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-24 2025-10-24 #> 14 prednisolone tablet           1 2025-10-26 2025-10-26 medications_simple #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   medication format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>   <chr>      <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #> 1 progynova  tablet           3 2025-08-21 2025-08-31 #> 2 progynova  tablet           6 2025-09-01 2025-09-11 #> 3 cyclogest  pessary          2 2025-09-03 2025-09-11 #> 4 clexane    injection        1 2025-09-08 2025-11-05

what: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: Calculates displays many medications remain taken specific date, based schedule medications start stop dates. Results can grouped either medication name format (e.g., tablet, injection).

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
code: medications_remaining(   meds = NULL,   group = c("medication", "format"),   on_date = Sys.Date(),   until_date = NULL )

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: meds Data frame containing medication schedule. Must following columns: medication (character/factor): Name medication format (character/factor): Format medication (e.g., pill, injection) quantity (numeric): Number units take per day start_date (Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD"): Date start taking medication stop_date (Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD"): Final date medication taken NULL, try use "pregnancy.medications" option. Required option set. group Character string specifying group results. One : "medication": Group medication name (default) "format": Group medication format on_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD", specifying date calculate remaining medications. Defaults current system date until_date Date character string representing date, e.g. "YYYY-MM-DD", specifying cut-date remaining medications. NULL, defaults latest stop_date medications.

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: Returns data frame containing remaining quantities, grouped specified. Assumes function called first thing day, .e. on_date's medications taken. data frame two columns: Either 'medication' 'format' depending grouping quantity: Total number units remaining medications remaining quantities > 0 included. medications remain, message printed console indicating , data frame 0 rows returned invisibly.

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: on_date, until_date start_date stop_date character vector, conversion Date handled anytime::anydate(). start_date NA row, row counted remaining quantities. stop_date NA, throws error.

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
text: pregnancy.medications: Data frame setting default medication schedule

title: Calculate remaining medications to be taken — medications_remaining
code: # Define medications table #' # Create example medication schedule meds <- data.frame(   medication = c("progynova", "prednisolone", "clexane"),   format = c("tablet", "tablet", "injection"),   quantity = c(3, 2, 1),   start_date = c("2025-04-21", "2025-04-26", "2025-05-08"),   stop_date = c("2025-04-30", "2025-05-07", "2025-09-05") )  # Calculate remaining medications medications_remaining(meds, on_date = "2025-04-21") #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   medication   quantity #>   <chr>           <int> #> 1 clexane           121 #> 2 prednisolone       24 #> 3 progynova          30  medications_remaining(meds, group = "format", on_date = "2025-04-21") #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   format    quantity #>   <chr>        <int> #> 1 injection      121 #> 2 tablet          54  # Calculate medications for a specified period medications_remaining(   meds = meds,   on_date = "2025-04-23",   until_date = "2025-04-30" ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   medication   quantity #>   <chr>           <int> #> 1 prednisolone       10 #> 2 progynova          24  # Set and use global medications option #' Store original medications setting (without message) original_medications <- getOption("pregnancy.medications") set_medications(pregnancy::medications) #> ✔ medications set. #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `medications` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the #>   `medications` argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `medications` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.medications = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `medications`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `medications` option with `get_medications()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.medications')`. medications_remaining(on_date = as.Date("2025-05-01")) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   medication   quantity #>   <chr>           <int> #> 1 LDA                18 #> 2 clexane           120 #> 3 cyclogest         140 #> 4 lubion             70 #> 5 prednisolone      307 #> 6 progynova         462  # Restore original medications setting (without message) options(pregnancy.medications = original_medications)

text: person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL: try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" option set.

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: functions invisibly return current person setting: get_person() returns current setting (character string) NULL set set_person() returns person value set

title: Set or get the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
code: # Store original setting (without messages) original_person <- getOption("pregnancy.person")  # Check current setting get_person() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.person` set as an option. #> ℹ The `person` argument defaults to "You".  # Set to first person (using string) set_person("I") #> ✔ person set as 'I' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'I'.  # Set to second person (using number) set_person(2) #> ✔ person set as 'You' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'You'.  # Set to a specific name set_person("Sarah") #> ✔ person set as 'Sarah' #> ℹ Functions in the pregnancy package will now use this `person` option. #> ℹ So, for this R session, you do not need to supply a value to the `person` #>   argument (unless you wish to override the option). #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, in your #>   ".Rprofile", set `options(pregnancy.person = ...)` #>   where ... is the value of `person`. #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> ℹ The person option is set as 'Sarah'.  # Restore original setting (without messages) options(pregnancy.person = original_person)

what: pregnancy: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy — pregnancy-package
title: pregnancy: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy — pregnancy-package
text: Provides functionality calculating pregnancy-related dates tracking medications pregnancy fertility treatment. Calculates due dates various starting points including last menstrual period IVF (Vitro Fertilisation) transfer dates, determines pregnancy progress given date, identifies specific pregnancy weeks reached. Includes medication tracking capabilities individuals undergoing fertility treatment pregnancy, allowing users monitor remaining doses quantities needed specified time periods. Designed tracking pregnancies supporting partners process, making use options personalise output messages. details due date calculations, see https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/05/methods--estimating--due-date.

title: pregnancy: Calculate and Track Dates and Medications During Pregnancy — pregnancy-package
text: Maintainer: Ella Kaye ella.kaye@gmail.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]
